body: Deloris Gillespie loved bargains, and when she found a good one -- milk at half-price, soap at a discount -- she bought in bulk and shared with her friends. She gave gifts to everyone, but would not accept any for herself. And when she shared recipes, ingredients were included. ''The last time, she gave me tilapia, Old Bay, buttermilk and hot
title: Mourners Honor Life of Woman Set Afire in Elevator

body: TJ GIRARD believes that most traditional serving vessels could use some spicing up. Parties are ''supposed to be fun, exciting and entertaining,'' she said. ''Why can't the presentation of food be part of that?'' As a designer at the New York catering company Pinch Food Design, which Ms. Girard, 31, owns with the chef Bob Spiegel, she has been busy
title: SHOPPING WITH TJ GIRARD; Pressed Into Service

body: She has come to be known for the brutal way in which she was killed: set ablaze inside an elevator, burned alive just feet from her apartment door. But in the modest six-floor building in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where she died, Deloris Gillespie was often celebrated for how she lived, her considerable generosity and slight eccentricity on
title: Before a Brutal Death, a Reputation for Generosity and Eccentricity

body: By the time Deloris Gillespie saw him, waiting on the other side of an elevator door, it was too late to escape. With her shopping bags in hand, she pushed open the door. There stood a man she knew, Jerome Isaac. He set upon her immediately, the authorities said, armed with a tank of fuel and a barbecue lighter, wearing white gloves and a surgical
title: Cornered by Attacker in Elevator, Fire Victim, 73, Had No Way Out

body: The surveillance video, its images disturbingly clear, ends with a woman being burned alive in the elevator of a Brooklyn apartment building on Saturday. But in the beginning, it seemed routine: a man dressed as an exterminator, wearing gloves, with a protective mask perched atop his head and carrying a container on his back, takes the elevator to
title: Woman Is Burned Alive in an Elevator in Brooklyn

body: PROSPECT HEIGHTS CO-OP $898,000 BROOKLYN: 262 Prospect Place (Vanderbilt Avenue), #2 A duplex consisting of four co-ops, with a total of four bedrooms and four baths, four fireplaces, a private garden and a top-floor bedroom deck, in a five-unit 1880s brownstone. body: TOM NISHIOKA twirled his wife, Alexandra Bloom, up and down the aisles of the Park Slope United Methodist Church on a recent Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn. As Dr. Bloom danced, the skirt of her strawberry red silk dress fluttered, and her cheeks glowed. She and her husband were there to renew their vows after eight years of a marriage that has
title: After the Years' Ups and Downs, Beginning Again

body: ''THERE are rumors of an owl,'' Michele Dreger told me in a hushed voice, as if the great bird might hear her and be scared off. ''Maybe, maybe, there might be, maybe, an owl.'' We were standing outside the Prospect Park Audubon Center on a recent sunny Saturday with 15 other birders for the weekly ''Introduction to Bird-Watching'' tour. ''Somebody
title: Winged Migrants in Their Brooklyn Pied-à-Terre

body: 552 Vanderbilt Avenue (Dean Street), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 576-6701; barchuko.com. Chuko is a ramen joint, but its finest dish is a salad. Mind you, that word does no justice to the lusty combination of raw and tempura kale, mined with golden raisins swollen from pickling, and speared with deep-fried strips of sweet potato ($7). Tangy
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; Chuko

title: TRANSACTIONS; Recent Sale

author: Twitter.com/ronlieber
body: For any fan of disruptive consumer technologies, watching Airbnb's rise has been all sorts of fun. Since its debut in 2008, the company, based in San Francisco, has booked more than two million nights of lodging all over the world. But it's not a hotel. Instead, it allows people to rent out their entire home or apartment -- or just a room or a bed
title: YOUR MONEY; Airbnb's Lodging Gets Tested, and a Mixed Bag Is the Result

body: Nine blocks from the steel shadow of Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, Gib Veconi circles Prospect Heights nightly in his 13-year-old Volvo wagon looking for a parking spot, like a buzzard scouring for a meal. Parking can be a blood sport in New York City, nowhere more so than along the crowded streets around the half-built Barclays Center in Downtown
title: Plan to Issue New Permits For Parking Is Debated

body: HALLOWEEN SPOOKTACULAR No one would deny that high school can have distressing, scary and even hair-raising moments. But the fearsome classroom episodes about to unfold in Jersey City have nothing to do with neglected Latin declensions or forgotten math theorems. And those zombies at the desks? They're not just sleep-deprived adolescents. Welcome
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

body: The last school bell on Friday was the beginning of unemployment for 672 employees in roughly 350 city schools -- school aides, parent coordinators, health aides and other support staff members. These are four of the school workers who were let go. CLIFTONIA JOHNSONCommunity associate, $37,000 a year When students at Marta Valle High School on the
title: Snapshots of Layoffs' Effect, From the Newly Unemployed

body: Some of them spent the past few days scouring the wanted ads on the New York City Department of Education's Web site. Others made sure they learned how to file for unemployment. Of the 777 New York City school employees who were sent pink slips two weeks ago, 672 lost their jobs on Friday in the largest single-agency layoff since Mayor Michael R.
title: 672 School Jobs Are Lost in Largest Single-Agency Layoff Under Bloomberg

body: SUPERHEROES have traditionally saved the planet while wearing capes, but other do-gooders prefer a different, if related form of outerwear. Think of Sherlock Holmes, Harry Potter or Jedi warriors, all clad in cloaks. Cloaks -- those coats with no sleeves, usually thigh-high or longer, almost always with a hood, and usually able to be wrapped or
title: Cloaks: Snuggies With Panache

author: E-mail: habitats@nytimes.com
body: THE leafy streets of Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, are lined with gracious brownstones and town houses built in the 19th century for well-to-do families who appreciated their stately proportions and exquisite detailing. Interspersed with these showstoppers are more modest three-story apartment buildings, home to the servants who tended to those grand
title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Inside a Plain Brick Wrapper

body: FOR most of his six years in New York, Paul Pinizzotto leased a three-bedroom duplex in a squat, no-frills building in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The rent ended up at $2,250 a month. Over the years, he rented out the extra bedrooms to a series of roommates. The apartment was spacious and sunny, but ''it was a place that I slept in,'' Mr. Pinizzotto said.
title: THE HUNT; Personality for Him; Practicality for Her

body: ''EVERYBODY has The Outfit -- the outfit they bought for America,'' Brooke Hauser writes in ''The New Kids: Big Dreams and Brave Journeys at a High School for Immigrant Teens'' (Free Press). ''The students who have lived in the country for longer have learned how to blend in better, disappearing in brand-name sneakers and low-riding jeans,'' Ms.
title: BOOKSHELF; Teenage Immigrant Dreams in the City

body: ALONG with the imported chefs and restaurateurs bringing Danish open-faced sandwiches, avant-garde Korean and Spanish fare, specialties from Beirut and Moscow, and even the flavors of Portland, Ore., to New York, some familiar faces on the local restaurant scene will try something new. A pizza master is opening a diner, and a high-end chef is doing
title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Fall's Bounty: Flavors From Home and Abroad

body: IT'S a challenge for restaurants to offer exciting lists of expensive or even moderately expensive wines. It's a far greater challenge for restaurants to offer a wide selection of captivating, inexpensive wines. It requires creativity, thoughtfulness and dedication to gather wines that may not return as big a profit as the more expensive choices on
title: THE POUR; Restaurant Bottles From the Bottom Up

body: On Thursday, New York City will burn to the ground. Preposterous? Not if you happen to be in the Nevada desert, outside Reno. There you can watch the city being burned. In effigy. That effigy is a structure that includes MetroCards, re-creations of four city bridges and a 20-foot-wide map of the subway -- without the G train. Before it combusts, it
title: Building New York Up, Only to Set It on Fire in the Nevada Desert

body: Miles has been going to Ace Bar all his life. His face has grayed there. Friends have come and gone. He never paid for a drink, but rarely walked out of the East Village bar with an empty stomach. He may have purged his dinner on the floor a time or two, his fellow bar patrons said, but who among them hadn't done the same? Over the past year,
title: As Bars Shut Doors To Dogs, a Tradition Ends

body: Opening REDFARM It has taken a good year for Ed Schoenfeld and Joe Ng to open their new venture. Only the red accents in the décor suggest that this 45-seat rough-hewn setting with yard-sale details is a Chinese restaurant. ''Unabashedly inauthentic'' is how Mr. Schoenfeld describes it. China, especially Mr. Ng's flair for dumplings, is the
title: Off The Menu

title: SQUARE FEET | THE 30-MINUTE INTERVIEW; Aaron Jungreis

body: LIKE many New Yorkers, Alan Tansey is planning an escape this summer -- in his case, a 370-mile journey north through New York State, over the Canadian border and into the heart of Montreal. But unlike the hordes who brave highway traffic or airport lines to break free of the city, Mr. Tansey will start enjoying himself as soon as he lugs his
title: SPOKES | SEAN PATRICK FARRELL; Bike Vacations Offer Freedom and Frugality

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: ZACH LINDER, who had always shared an apartment, had every intention of renting a place of his own. Envisioning a small one-bedroom in a residential Brooklyn neighborhood, he drew up a budget: ''$1,400 was my soft ceiling and $1,500 was my hard ceiling,'' he said. ''I thought I was being pretty reasonable and not tremendously overly neurotic and
title: THE HUNT; When the Math Says Go Ahead and Buy

body: LANDLORDS in New York City can afford to be picky. With a vacancy rate in Manhattan of under 1 percent, apartments sometimes rent in hours, not days or weeks. Good tenants are not that hard to find. On top of that, evicting problem tenants can be expensive and time consuming. So, most landlords here require a lot of information. They want to see a
title: GETTING STARTED; You Say You're a Dream Renter? Prove It.

body: THREE young girls zipped across the crowded dance floor, dresses fluttering, as a new D.J. took the stage. Their parents watched from beneath a small grove of plum and oak trees, drinking beers and discussing the exhibition of Ryan Trecartin videos. Nearby, two intricately coiffed hipsters in tight black cut-offs dipped their feet in a pool and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | LONG ISLAND CITY; Is It Summer? Time to Party At the Museum

body: It is a badge of urban pride: knowing how to walk around New York City without a map. But the Bloomberg administration believes that residents and tourists alike could use a bit of help sometimes. So the city is planning a new system of street signage intended to help pedestrians get from here to there with as little confusion as possible. The
title: City Signs to Help Pedestrians (They Aren't Just for Tourists)

body: Budget belt-tightening threatens to send school librarians the way of the card catalog. The schools superintendent in Lancaster, Pa., said he had to eliminate 15 of the district's 20 librarians to save full-day kindergarten classes. In the Salem-Keizer school district in Oregon, all 48 elementary and middle school librarians would lose their jobs
title: In Lean Times, Schools Squeeze Out Librarians

body: If you thought the last thing brownstone Brooklyn needed was another purveyor of artisanal foods, you are officially wrong. Ample Hills Creamery, a new ice cream shop in Prospect Heights, closed four days after opening, but only because the demand was so great: customers bought out all 130 gallons of homemade ice cream by last Saturday night. ''It
title: CITY ROOM; An Ice Cream Shop So Good, It Closes After Just 4 Days

title: The Listings

It's a tale of love, class, betrayal, supernatural
title: The Listings

body: WHEN 1 of a Find, a high-end vintage clothing store, arrived on Lincoln Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, during the spring of 2008, it was greeted with bland indifference. This is, after all, quite possibly the least chic neighborhood in New York City: a place where the closest thing to a club scene is cargo pants-clad, nose-pierced damsels gamboling
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; Not So New, But Not Forgotten

body: Brian Smith, the owner of Ample Hills Creamery, right, a bright shop that just opened in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is scooping salted caramel, maple-bacon, chocolate stout with pretzels, all-natural bubble gum tinted with beet juice and 19 other flavors, including chocolate and vanilla. He custom blends his bases (some with eggs, some not), so by
title: FOOD STUFF; Satisfy That Hankering for Mixed Vegetable Ice Cream

body: 9:51 p.m. | Updated The United Federation of Teachers filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in an effort to halt two tools the city's Education Department uses to change the school system: closing schools for poor performance and giving charter schools space in buildings occupied by traditional public schools. The litigation, filed in State Supreme Court,
title: Teachers' Union Files Suit To Stop School Closings

body: As a parent of a student who started in the inaugural first-grade class at Community Roots Charter School in Brooklyn in 2006, Chris Thompson has watched his son grow up in an elementary school that has transformed itself from an experiment in progressive education to one of District 13's most popular destinations for young families. When Mr.
title: A Battle for Space by Charter and Traditional Schools Upsets an Expansion Plan

title: Police Look Into a Complaint by New York's Schools Chancellor After His Car Was Stopped

body: It's illegal to smoke inside the State Supreme Court building at 60 Centre Street in Manhattan. But for the Vanity Fair bash held on the courthouse's portico on Wednesday night in celebration of the Tribeca Film Festival, there was apparently no problem with bartenders offering free packs of Natural American Spirit cigarettes. Some guests puffed
title: NOCTURNALIST; You Singin' To Me?

title: Spare Times

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society (Friday through Sunday, Wednesday and Thursday) The talk ''Mixed-Colonial-American-Ancestry: Are You Related to Royals?'' features Pearl Duncan, an African-American author who shares how she used family nicknames, DNA and genealogy to trace her lineage to families named Opare of the Akan
title: Spare Times

body: Everyone knows that some of the best people-watching in New York City can be had in Hell's Hundred Acres. Those on the hunt for a middle-class complex would be well advised to check out the Gas House District. Hankering for bagels and a schmear? Get thee to Bloomingdale, stat. All are names, gone and widely forgotten, of the areas currently known
title: ProCro, SoBro, FiDi, BoCoCa: A Lawmaker Says, 'Enough'

body: ON the north side of Prospect Heights in northwestern Brooklyn, construction workers are busy building the Barclays Center, the future home of the New Jersey Nets. On the neighborhood's south side sit several of the borough's most venerable cultural institutions and attractions. And in between is an evolving neighborhood that is also a blend of the
title: LIVING IN | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Tucked Between Past and Future

body: Opening THEATER BAR In case you are wondering what happened to the furnishings from David Bouley's Danube (now Brushstroke), you'll find the striped velvet Jacques Garcia banquettes in Albert Trummer's 50-seat bar and lounge. The actual bar is theatrically set, up a couple of steps and beneath a proscenium. Four bartenders each mix drinks to
title: Off the Menu

author: E-mail: oneducation@nytimes.com
body: In a city where so many public schools are segregated by race and wealth, Public School 9 in Brooklyn is an exception. It has a substantial number of poor children, with about 75 percent receiving subsidized lunches. And because it is in a gentrifying neighborhood, Prospect Heights, the school also has a sizable number of yuppie children. The
title: ON EDUCATION; A City School's Uphill Fight Over Sharing Space With a Charter

body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History (Monday) ''A Hitchhiker's Guide to Habitable Planets in Our Galaxy'' is a lecture by Linda Elkins-Tanton, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on what is known about planetary formation; part of Hayden Planetarium's ''Frontiers in Astrophysics'' lecture series.
title: Spare Times

body: Two years ago, St. Joseph's Church in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, seemed to be headed for extinction. Attendance at Sunday Masses had fallen below 100. The 159-year-old parish's buildings were crumbling and its coffers were empty. Today, the scaffolding outside bustles with workers. Sundays draw more than 300 worshipers, many of them families with
title: NOW ARRIVING; Mexicans Fill Pews, Even as the Church Is Slow to Adapt

body: Freddy's, an iconoclastic Brooklyn dive bar that once stood in the way of a bulldozer, has returned -- at least in the physical sense. Relocated 32 blocks away, Freddy's still has the same red mahogany bar, more of the same sardonic art objects, and some of the same customers, who say it is cleaner and warmer than the old place. Whether Freddy's is
title: SUNSET PARK JOURNAL; The Transmigration of a Brooklyn Saloon

body: 'SKELLIG' When the title character in ''Skellig'' is revealed to have wings, you may worry that you've wandered into the mawkish realm of ''Touched by an Angel'' and other vintage pop entertainment about heavenly messengers. But don't be fooled: if this unusual play has a presiding deity, it's Darwin. The script abounds in references to human
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Irish and Downtown A food tour of Lower Manhattan that will cover all things Irish will be held Saturday from noon to 3 p.m., with a pub crawl, $25: (212) 835-2750, downtownny.com/foodtours. Cupcake Sort of Tourism A tour of cupcake bakeries in Chelsea and Greenwich Village on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. will start at Billy's Bakery, 184 Ninth
title: Calendar

body: THE very mention of certain apartment buildings in New York evokes a genteel world of wealth, power and discretion. At the Dakota, 740 Park Avenue or 15 Central Park West a gantlet of daunting prices, white-gloved doormen, and in some cases Kremlinesque co-op boards, keep mere mortals from a nirvana of sun-drenched penthouses, richly paneled
title: 'It' Buildings Of The Other Boroughs

body: LIKE thousands of other New Yorkers, Jason Henkle throws a leg over a bicycle every day and pedals to work. Unlike most of his fellow riders, Mr. Henkle built his understated single-speed bike by hand. Mr. Henkle is among a small group of dedicated New York cyclists who have begun building their own bicycle frames. Their hand-constructed cycles are
title: SPOKES; The Hands That Steer Are Building the Bikes

body: Lucy Allison Baker and Alexander James Brandes were married Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Edward Schecter officiated. The bride, 29, is a columnist in Brooklyn for seriouseats.com, and is the author of ''The Boozy Baker: 75 Recipes for Spirited Sweets'' (Running Press, 2010). She is also the publicist for
title: Lucy Baker, Alexander Brandes

body: THE bar at Soho House was hopping as those in the members-only crowd clinked glasses and regaled one another at a midlevel roar. But the real drama was playing out one floor down, in the club's library, where a small cross-section of New York City was held rapt by tales seldom overheard in polite company: love disintegrating amid differences in
title: All Around Town, Stories Well Told

body: Opening BROOKLYN STAR Joaquin Baca had a fire in his bar-restaurant about a year ago and is finally ready to reopen in a larger space nearby, with the same inventive comfort-food menu. Are you comforted by tripe chili? Fried pig tails? Chicken and dumplings? Meatloaf on country white bread? Get ready: 593 Lorimer Street (Metropolitan Avenue),
title: Off the Menu

body: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor's Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

author: E-mail: appraisal@nytimes.com
body: For six months, Emily Huters and her husband, Trey Hatch, spent five hours every Sunday morning taking turns caring for their son, Henry, so they could clean up their loft for open houses. They packed up Henry's play mat and toys, tried to remove smashed raisins from every crevice of his highchair and moved his hefty nursing chair to a neighbor's
title: THE APPRAISAL; Have an Open House Every Sunday? Or Play With Henry?

body: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction. Brad Estabrooke
title: THE TIPSY DIARIES; Pride of Place In Every Drop

body: Opening EMBER ROOM No longer associated with Kittichai in SoHo, Ian Chalermkittichai has gone back to using his full surname. Now he has teamed with Todd English to create Asian-inflected barbecue in a space sheathed in dark reclaimed boards, some looking as if they came from a wood pile out back. A special oven is the centerpiece between the bar
title: Off the Menu

body: Jason Kidd was the Nets' All-Star point guard when he attended the naming ceremony for the organization's new arena in Brooklyn four years ago. Since then, Kidd's home has changed, and so has the Nets' since they vacated the Izod Center in the Meadowlands after last season. Last weekend he returned to New Jersey, as a point guard for the Dallas
title: New Arena For the Nets Is Sprouting In Brooklyn

body: Tajeme Sylvester was a carpenter, a handyman and a poet. He was known as an impressive craftsman, whether renovating a brownstone or constructing a set for an Off Broadway theater. After hours, he was a fixture on the party circuit, dancing to house music, hip-hop and whatever else moved him. On Jan. 10, he became a statistic: the seventh homicide
title: RED HOOK JOURNAL; A Vibrant Force Lost, While an Arts Scene Mourns

body: DIANA JENSEN bought her first place nearly five years ago, paying $237,000 for a two-bedroom co-op in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. Ms. Jensen, an art teacher at the Bank Street School for Children in Manhattan, used the master bedroom as a studio for painting and drawing. But she was never quite happy with her home. ''Having grown up in Manhattan,'' she
title: THE HUNT; This Time Park Slope, or Close to It

body: WITH its pyrotechnics, suspenders and tattoos, the cocktail scene in New York appears, at times, to revolve around a troupe of Barnum & Bailey escapees. But those who frequent Weather Up, a Prohibition-style cocktail lounge, need not worry. Its 34-year-old namesake and owner, Kathryn Weatherup, is tall and blond, an unbearded lady. She is what, in
title: UP CLOSE; The Anti-Banter Bartender
